Award.AbstractNarration:
Standards for data exchange are critical to the development of any field. They enable researchers and practitioners to exchange information reliably, apply a variety of tools to their problems, and reproduce scientific results. The COmputational MOdeling in Biology NEtwork (COMBINE) was created in 2010 to organize standardization efforts for systems biology. This effort includes, among others, the systems biology markup language (SBML) for mathematical modeling; the biological pathways exchange language (BioPaX) for describing pathways; the systems biology graphical notation (SBGN) for visual representations; and the synthetic biology open language (SBOL). The purpose of this grant is to support travel expenses for students, postdoctoral scholars, and participants from underrepresented groups to attend COMBINE 2016 to be hosted by Newcastle University in Newcastle, UK from September 19th to 23rd, 2016 (http://co.mbine.org/events/COMBINE_2016).

This workshop will not only be a valuable educational experience for the student participants, but it will also provide them a valuable opportunity to interact with international researchers. Since this event will be held in the United Kingdom and will bring researchers from all over the world (the last one held in Salt Lake City, UT had representatives from six continents), this meeting will enhance and foster new international collaborations in the area of standards for data representation and exchange in biology. The United Kingdom has been a leader in systems and synthetic biology research and standard development. In particular, the UK government has identified synthetic biology as a national strategic research area (funding it with over Â£50m to date, https://www.gov.uk/government/groups/synthetic-biology-leadership-council) and has produced a Synthetic Biology Roadmap for the UK (http://www.rcuk.ac.uk/publications/reports/syntheticbiologyroadmap/). In fact, it can be argued that the US and UK have the largest research programs in these areas. Collaborations between these two countries in this area are essential to success. The UK's Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council (BBSRC) and NSF have very recently initiated a joint funding effort that in particular includes synthetic biology (http://www.bbsrc.ac.uk/funding/filter/nsfbio-lead-agency-pilot/). Indeed, it is crucial that the standards developed are not US or UK standards, but truly world data representation standards.

NSF support (Funding provided from the Directorate of Computer Information Science and Engineering and the Office of International Science and Engineering is gratefully acknowledged) ensures a technical and diverse set of undergraduate, graduate, and post doctoral students can attend the conference to present research, learn more about the field, and expand their networking opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided partial travel support for 9 students and postdoctoral fellows to attend COMBINE Forum in Newcastle, United Kingdom in September 2016 (http://co.mbine.org/events/COMBINE_2016), and one undergraduate student to attend COMBINE Forum in Milan, Italy in October 2017 (http://co.mbine.org/events/COMBINE_2017).  This event is organized annually by the Computational Modeling in Biology Network (COMBINE).  The goal of this event is to promote the development of the standards and supporting infrastructure for systems and synthetic biology, as well as, interoperability between these standards.  The primary COMBINE standards are the systems biology markup language (SBML), systems biology graphical notation (SBGN), simulation experiment description markup language (SED-ML), the biological pathway (BioPAX) description language, the cell markup language (CellML), and the synthetic biology open language (SBOL). This was the first COMBINE Forum in which SBOL participated.
At COMBINE, the first day is a seminar day composed of invited talks.  In particular, we had four sessions each with 2 speakers, 2 on modeling and 1 each on medical applications and data exchange. The following four days were composed of contributed talks in the morning, and breakout discussion sections in the afternoon with posters during the breaks.  All supported students presented either a talk. The goal of the breakout sessions is to consider improvements for the COMBINE data standards, and all of the supported students participated in these discussions.  While many of the breakouts focused on individual standards, there were some that involved multiple standards.  For example, the SBOL Visual and SBGN communities discussed integration of their standards.  This grant was instrumental to the success of this meeting.  Many of the people working on standard development are students and postdocs that either volunteer their time or have limited resources for travel. Without this grant, it would have been prohibitively expensive for many of the participants to attend.  This was a great experience for the students and postdocs enabling them to share their work and interact with the larger community, and contribute to the next versions of these standards.
